Acute HIV infection can be associated with pancytopenia, relative lymphocytosis, and splenomegaly. The peripheral-blood smear can reveal an increase in large granular lymphocyte cells, which are usually of T-lymphocyte origin.

D) INCORRECT:

None of the other options listed are characterized by lymphocytes with hairy projections. Chronic lymphocytic leukemia is characterized by an increase of mature-appearing B lymphocytes.

E) CORRECT:

Hairy-cell leukemia is an uncommon hematologic cancer characterized by an accumulation of abnormal B lymphocytes. It is usually classified as a subtype of chronic lymphoid leukemia. Hairy-cell leukemia makes up approximately 2% of all leukemias.

Hairy-cell leukemia can manifest, in advanced stages, with B symptoms, pancytopenia, and marked splenomegaly. Monocytopenia is also a common finding. Pancytopenia occurs in relation to several clinicopathological findings, including infiltration of the bone marrow by hairy-cell leukemia cells, splenic sequestration of blood cells because of massive splenomegaly, and bone-marrow fibrosis. In most cases of hairy-cell leukemia, peripheral-blood specimens reveal atypical B lymphocytes with radial hairy projections. In patients with hairy-cell leukemia who do not have lymphocytes with the typical hairy projections, the diagnosis may rest on documenting high levels of soluble CD25 in the serum and detecting cell surface expression of CD103.

Cladribine has emerged as the first-line therapy for hairy-cell leukemia and is associated with a high remission rate as well as durability of remission, lasting for many years.

Key learning point: Pancytopenia in association with splenomegaly, B symptoms, monocytopenia, and atypical lymphocytes with hairy projections is characteristic of hairy-cell leukemia.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old man presents with fatigue, weight loss, and a swelling in his neck that he first noticed 3 weeks ago. He was diagnosed with HIV infection 5 years ago; at that time, he was asymptomatic with a CD4 count of 490 cells per mm3 (reference range, 400–1600), and antiretroviral therapy was not prescribed. Since then, he has not followed up with his provider despite repeated attempts to contact him.
About one month ago, he was able to play basketball without any difficulties, but he is now having trouble walking from the parking lot to his apartment. He reports night sweats and a weight loss of 6.8 kg.
On physical examination, he is tachycardic and has a palpable 5-cm mass in the right side of his neck, right axillary fullness, and splenomegaly.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Follicular lymphoma is a more indolent lymphoma and is less prevalent among people with HIV than the more aggressive lymphomas.

B) INCORRECT:

People with HIV are at increased risk for human papillomavirus-related squamous-cell carcinoma of the tonsil, but the rapid time course and systemic symptoms reported by this patient would be atypical.

C) CORRECT:

People with HIV are at least 70 times more likely to develop non-Hodgkin lymphoma than people without HIV. The risk for HIV-related lymphoma increases with greater immunosuppression; the disease occurs predominantly in patients with CD4 counts <100 cells per mm3 who have not been receiving long-term antiretroviral therapy. Rarely, cases occur in patients with higher CD4-cell counts but generally in those not receiving treatment.

Burkitt lymphoma is an aggressive non-Hodgkin lymphoma associated with c-myc translocation, usually in association with Epstein-Barr virus infection.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a young man with HIV, a rapidly enlarging neck mass, splenomegaly, night sweats, and weight loss is Burkitt lymphoma.

D) INCORRECT:

Infectious mononucleosis can cause fatigue and lymphadenopathy, but the lymphadenopathy would not be as impressive as it is in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Kaposi sarcoma usually manifests with skin nodules and plaques. Only in rare cases does it primarily involve the lymph nodes, usually in conjunction with mucosal disease.

questions.text:
A 51-year-old man presents with progressive fatigue, early satiety, and fevers without chills. He has a history of hepatitis C virus infection (genotype 3a) diagnosed 5 years ago. After 3 months of antiviral therapy, he discontinued treatment because of fatigue and mild depression. He has not had dental work or any procedures within the past year. Review of systems is negative for anorexia, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. He takes no medications except for periodic ibuprofen.
He drinks one to two beers per week and has no history of heavy alcohol use. He currently smokes cigarettes and has a 5-pack-year history. He does not use illicit drugs.
He weighs 70 kg, which is 3.6 kg lower than when measured one year ago. He does not appear ill but looks tired. His general examination is unremarkable other than a spleen that is palpable 9 cm below the left costal margin and several 2- to 5-cm lymph nodes in the cervical, supraclavicular, axillary, and inguinal regions bilaterally.
Laboratory results are as follows:

Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Endocarditis must always be considered in a patient with fever and splenomegaly, but subacute bacterial endocarditis would not cause diffuse lymphadenopathy.

B) INCORRECT:

Although this patient is at risk for cirrhosis, cirrhosis is not associated with lymphadenopathy.

C) INCORRECT:

Epstein-Barr virus can cause lymphadenopathy, but it is most typically associated with fever and pharyngitis. Thrombocytopenia is only rarely associated with Epstein-Barr virus infection.

D) CORRECT:

Hepatitis C virus (HCV) is associated with the development of lymphomas of B-cell origin, particularly splenic lymphoma. The lymphoma often regresses when the patient’s HCV infection is treated.

Key learning point: In a patient with hepatitis C virus infection, the development of splenomegaly and diffuse lymphadenopathy is most consistent with a diagnosis of low-grade lymphoma.

E) INCORRECT:

HIV infection more typically causes lymphopenia and anemia; lymphocytosis is an uncommon finding with acute HIV infection. HIV infection is associated with an increased risk of high-grade lymphoma, so HIV testing should be performed in patients with new lymphoma diagnoses.

questions.text:
A 41-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with abdominal distention and pain. Her symptoms first started 2 weeks ago and have worsened. She also reports unintended weight loss of 3 kg, ongoing chills, and soaking night sweats.
She was born and raised in Mexico City and immigrated to the United States 3 years ago. She has no recollection of a tuberculosis diagnosis for herself or any close family members.
On physical examination, she is afebrile and in moderate distress, with a heart rate of 118 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 116/73 mm Hg. Her examination is notable for several palpable cervical and inguinal lymph nodes, as well as an enlarged spleen that is tender to palpation. Her abdomen is mildly distended.
A rapid HIV test is positive. The patient is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative. Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
8.1
12.0–16.0


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
1300
4500–11,000


Platelet count (per mm3)
89,000
150,000–350,000



Lactate dehydrogenase (U/liter)
1860
100–190



Uric acid (mg/dL)
16.3
1.5–6.0



Creatinine (mg/dL)
2.3
0.6–1.1


Potassium (mEq/liter)
6.2
3.5–5.0


Phosphate (mg/dL)
6.8
3.0–4.5


Calcium (mg/dL)
7.1
9.0–10.5


In addition to administering fluids and performing a tissue biopsy, what is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Initiation of antiretroviral therapy is important for people with HIV, but the acuity of the current scenario necessitates immediate treatment with fluids and medications to address the uric acid elevation.

B) INCORRECT:

In addition to high-grade lymphoma, which most closely fits the presentation in this case, the differential diagnosis of an elevated LDH level in a person with HIV includes pneumocystis pneumonia, which is treated with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, and tuberculosis, which is treated with at least three antitubercular agents. Other possible diagnoses include toxoplasmosis, histoplasmosis, septic shock, and lung infarction, but the differential diagnosis narrows to high-grade lymphoma and histoplasmosis when the LDH level exceeds 1000 U/liter.

C) INCORRECT:

A bone-marrow biopsy is commonly part of the workup and staging of suspected lymphoma; however, stabilization of the patient is the first step in management.

D) INCORRECT:

In addition to high-grade lymphoma, which most closely fits the presentation in this case, the differential diagnosis of an elevated LDH level in a person with HIV includes pneumocystis pneumonia, which is treated with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, and tuberculosis, which is treated with at least three antitubercular agents. Other possible diagnoses include toxoplasmosis, histoplasmosis, septic shock, and lung infarction, but the differential diagnosis narrows to high-grade lymphoma and histoplasmosis when the LDH level exceeds 1000 U/liter.

E) CORRECT:

Spontaneous tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) occurs most commonly in patients with very aggressive lymphomas (e.g., Burkitt lymphoma) or acute lymphoblastic leukemias. The hallmark of TLS is increased cell turnover marked by elevated serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), uric acid, potassium, and phosphate, as well as decreased serum calcium.

Management of TLS in high-risk patients, such as those with Burkitt lymphoma, includes intravenous fluids and (if the uric acid level is very high) rasburicase to degrade the existing uric acid to a water-soluble renally excreted metabolite. Without treatment, kidney failure will worsen. Rasburicase is highly effective in malignancy-associated hyperuricemia. Of note, rasburicase is contraindicated in individuals with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency; patients at increased risk for G6PD deficiency (for example, individuals of African or Mediterranean ancestry) should be screened for G6PD deficiency before starting rasburicase.

Key learning point: Spontaneous tumor lysis syndrome can occur in patients with Burkitt lymphoma and is treated with intravenous fluids and rasburicase.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old woman has a one-month history of progressive abdominal pain. A mass is found on examination and confirmed on CT. Tissue biopsy reveals findings consistent with a lymphoma that stains positive for the B-cell antigen CD20.
Which one of the following treatments is most likely to be effective for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cetuximab binds to the epidermal growth factor receptor and in many solid malignancies.

B) INCORRECT:

Alemtuzumab is used to treat leukemias with cells that express CD52.

C) INCORRECT:

Bevacizumab interferes with vascular endothelial growth factor A and inhibits the growth of tumors such as colon cancer and renal-cell carcinoma.

D) CORRECT:

CD20 is a cell-surface marker of B cells and neoplasms derived from B-cell lineages. Some of the tumors that express CD20 can be treated with a regimen that includes the anti-CD20 monoclonal antibody rituximab.

Key learning point: Lymphomas that express the B-cell antigen CD20 can be treated effectively with the anti-CD20 antibody rituximab.

E) INCORRECT:

Gemtuzumab ozogamicin binds to CD33 and is used to treat some forms of acute myelogenous leukemia.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man presents with fevers, night sweats, and fatigue. He has hepatosplenomegaly on examination.
CT of the chest reveals a large mediastinal mass. Subsequent biopsy of the chest mass reveals a germinal center B-cell lymphoma.
Which one of the following drugs is most likely to be included in this patient’s treatment regimen?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Omalizumab is an anti-immunoglobulin E monoclonal antibody used to treat severe, persistent asthma and chronic urticaria.

B) CORRECT:

B-cell lymphomas often manifest with symptoms such as fatigue, weight loss, night sweats, and fever of unknown origin, as well as a nodal mass, most commonly in the neck, abdomen, or mediastinum. B-cell lymphomas typically express the CD20 antigen as a surface protein.

Rituximab is a chimeric anti-CD20 monoclonal antibody used to treat diffuse B-cell lymphoma and leukemias. Rituximab in combination with traditional CHOP therapy (cyclophosphamide, hydroxydaunorubicin, vincristine, and prednisone or prednisolone) is more effective than CHOP treatment alone.

Key learning point: The biologic response modifier with efficacy against B-cell lymphoma is rituximab.

C) INCORRECT:

Cetuximab is an epidermal growth factor receptor inhibitor used to treat metastatic colorectal cancer.

D) INCORRECT:

Infliximab is an antitumor necrosis factor monoclonal antibody used to treat rheumatoid arthritis.

E) INCORRECT:

Alemtuzumab is an anti-CD52 monoclonal antibody used to treat chronic lymphocytic leukemia, cutaneous T-cell lymphoma, and other T-cell lymphomas.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the office because of a 2-month history of chest pain, dry cough, and shortness of breath. He describes two painless masses in his neck, which he says appeared 4 months ago and are progressively increasing in size. During this time, he has had several week-long episodes of fever, and his clothes have become looser. Temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F). Physical examination shows two nontender, fixed cervical lymph nodes on either side of the neck, which are approximately 2.2 cm and 4.5 cm in size. The tip of the spleen is palpated 3 cm below the left costal margin. An x-ray of the chest shows discrete widening of the superior mediastinum. Which of the following is most appropriate to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Leukocyte count is a nonspecific marker that should be obtained in all patients with suspected hematological malignancy. This patient most likely has lymphoma, which could cause either an elevation or decrease in the WBC count, so his leukocyte count would not be a reliable diagnostic marker.

B) INCORRECT:

Fine needle aspiration is commonly employed to assess solid lesions such as breast masses and thyroid nodules. However, fine needle aspiration would not provide enough tissue in the setting of suspected malignant lymphoma, so it is insufficient for obtaining an accurate diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

A CT scan of the chest would be useful to rule out the presence of lung cancer. This patient's chest pain, cough, shortness of breath, and weight loss are all consistent with a possible lung malignancy. However, his painless lymphadenopathy, cyclical fevers, and splenomegaly make lymphoma a more likely etiology. CT scan is helpful for staging lymphoma, but not in confirming the diagnosis and histological subtype.

D) INCORRECT:

Bone marrow aspiration is a valuable test for staging lymphoma. This is more applicable to non-Hodgkin lymphoma, as it involves the bone marrow in 30–50% of cases. In cases of Hodgkin lymphoma, only 6% of patients have bone marrow involvement. While a bone marrow aspiration may become necessary for staging in this patient, this test would not be the next best step in making a definite diagnosis.

E) CORRECT:

Excisional biopsy of a lymph node is the most appropriate next step in confirming the diagnosis of suspected malignant lymphoma. Histopathological analysis of the biopsy specimen allows for the distinction between Hodgkin lymphoma and non-Hodgkin lymphoma, which is essential for determining further staging and a proper treatment regimen. Painless, fixed, slowly progressing lymph node enlargement (generalized or localized) should always raise suspicion for malignant disease.
questions.hint: Malignant lymphoma must be ruled out in a patient presenting with multifocal painless lymphadenopathy, recurrent fever, weight loss, and splenomegaly.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presents with fatigue, weight loss, and a swelling in his neck that he first noticed 3 weeks ago. He was diagnosed with HIV infection 5 years ago; at that time, he was asymptomatic with a CD4 count of 490 cells/mm3 (reference range, 400–1600), and antiretroviral therapy was not prescribed. Since then, he has not followed up with his provider despite repeated attempts to contact him. About one month ago, he was able to play basketball without any difficulties, but he is now having trouble walking from the parking lot to his apartment. He reports night sweats and a weight loss of 6.8 kg. On physical examination, he is tachycardic and has a palpable 5-cm mass in the right side of his neck, right axillary fullness, and splenomegaly. Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Follicular lymphoma is a more indolent lymphoma and is less prevalent among people with HIV than the more aggressive lymphomas.

B) INCORRECT:

People with HIV are at increased risk for human papillomavirus-related squamous-cell carcinoma of the tonsil, but the rapid time course and systemic symptoms reported by this patient would be atypical.

C) CORRECT:

People with HIV are at least 70 times more likely to develop non-Hodgkin lymphoma than people without HIV. The risk for HIV-related lymphoma increases with greater immunosuppression; the disease occurs predominantly in patients with CD4 counts <100 cells per mm3 who have not been receiving long-term antiretroviral therapy. Rarely, cases occur in patients with higher CD4-cell counts but generally in those not receiving treatment.

Burkitt lymphoma is an aggressive non-Hodgkin lymphoma associated with c-myc translocation, usually in association with Epstein-Barr virus infection.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a young man with HIV, a rapidly enlarging neck mass, splenomegaly, night sweats, and weight loss is Burkitt lymphoma.

D) INCORRECT:

Infectious mononucleosis can cause fatigue and lymphadenopathy, but the lymphadenopathy would not be as impressive as it is in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Kaposi sarcoma usually manifests with skin nodules and plaques. Only in rare cases does it primarily involve the lymph nodes, usually in conjunction with mucosal disease.
questions.hint: A biopsy specimen from a lymph node would show a high proliferation index and “starry sky” appearance.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man comes to your clinic because of recurrent nosebleeds that occur with light trauma or spontaneously during the day. Over the past 6 months, he has experienced weakness, fatigue, a 10-kg weight loss, poor appetite, and abdominal discomfort. He does not report night sweats. His temperature is 37.5°C, pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg. The spleen is palpated 10 cm below the left costal margin. Multiple bruises are noted on both upper extremities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin (Hgb), blood
98 g/L (125–170)


Hematocrit (Hct), blood
0.299 L/L (0.38–0.50)


White blood cell (WBC) count, blood
4.5 × 109/L (3.5–10.5)


Neutrophils, absolute, blood
1.35 × 109/L (2.0–7.5)


Platelet count, blood
74 × 109/L (130–380)


Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), blood
410 IU/L (100–205)


Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase activity
Detected


A peripheral blood smear detects tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase activity. Which one of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?

choices.text: Transfusion of packed red blood cells.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In patients with hairy cell leukemia, rituximab is used to treat refractory or relapsed cases that do not respond to the first-line treatment. Another treatment modality is more appropriate for this patient at this time.

B) INCORRECT:

Transfusion of packed RBCs is indicated in patients with hemoglobin < 70–80 g/L who have active bleeding and/or hemodynamic instability, symptomatic anemia, or cardiovascular conditions in which a low Hb further increases the risk of poor organ perfusion and tissue oxygenation. Although this patient's laboratory results indicate anemia, the transfusion threshold has not been reached and the treatment of the underlying condition should be the first priority.

C) INCORRECT:

The transfusion threshold for platelet transfusion is a platelet count < 10 × 109/L regardless of the clinical findings and a platelet count < 50 × 109/L in symptomatic patients (e.g., with active bleeding). Although this patient has thrombocytopenia, the transfusion threshold has not been reached and treatment of the underlying condition should be the first priority.

D) CORRECT:

Chemotherapy with cladribine is the first-line treatment for hairy cell leukemia. Treatment is indicated in patients with symptoms of cytopenia, splenomegaly, and/or constitutional symptoms. The majority of patients achieve complete remission with cladribine. Pentostatin is another purine analog that can be used as an initial treatment for hairy cell leukemia or as an alternative to cladribine if the initial treatment fails.

Key learning point: Cladribine, a purine analog, is the first-line treatment for symptomatic hairy cell leukemia, leading to high rates of complete remission.

E) INCORRECT:

Although cyclophosphamide is routinely used for induction therapy of many leukemias and lymphomas, it is not, however, effective in the treatment of hairy cell leukemia.
questions.hint: Peripheral blood smear in this patient would also show abnormally large WBCs with centrally placed nuclei and multiple fine, radial, hair-like cytoplasmic projections, indicating hairy cell leukemia.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with a rapidly enlarging, painless mass in his neck over the past six weeks. He reports associated drenching night sweats and an unintentional 6.8-kg (15-lb) weight loss during this period. He does not report a fever or sore throat. His medical history is unremarkable. On examination, a 6-cm, firm, non-tender, fixed mass is palpated in the right anterior cervical chain. Mild splenomegaly is also noted. Laboratory studies show elevated lactate dehydrogenase and uric acid levels. An excisional biopsy of the mass is performed. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Burkitt lymphoma is a highly aggressive B-cell lymphoma known for extremely rapid growth and elevated LDH. It is rare and typically affects children and young adults. Although its aggressive nature fits parts of the clinical picture, this patient's age makes another lymphoma a more likely diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Follicular lymphoma is a common type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma that typically presents with painless lymphadenopathy in older adults. It typically manifests as an indolent, or slow-growing, lymphoma. This patient's history of a rapidly enlarging mass over only six weeks is inconsistent with the typical waxing and waning course of follicular lymphoma, which often develops over months to years.

C) CORRECT:

Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) is the most common non-Hodgkin lymphoma in adults. Key features include older age, a rapidly enlarging mass, and the presence of B symptoms (drenching night sweats, weight loss). The elevated LDH and uric acid levels reflect a high tumor burden and rapid cell turnover, which are characteristic of this aggressive malignancy. DLBCL can present with nodal involvement, as seen here, or in extranodal sites. The diagnosis is confirmed by an excisional biopsy showing a diffuse proliferation of large, atypical B lymphocytes. Curative treatment typically involves chemoimmunotherapy.

D) INCORRECT:

Hodgkin lymphoma can present with painless cervical lymphadenopathy and B symptoms. However, it has a bimodal age distribution, with a primary peak in young adulthood (20s–30s). Although a second peak occurs in older adults, another lymphoma is more common in this patient's age group. Furthermore, the very rapid growth described is more characteristic of an aggressive non-Hodgkin lymphoma.
